conclusion: The problem involves electric potentials and forces on a charged particle.
Four points A, B, M, and N are at a distance of sqrt(2)L from O, with O as the midpoint between A and B.
Two positive charges Q are fixed at points A and B.
The electric potential along the ON axis is given in figure (b), and the acceleration of a small ball S1 with charge Q falling from M to N is given in figure (c).
The task is to find the magnitude of the electric force on the small ball S1 at point M.
A and B create an electric field around them, and the electric potential at any point is the sum of the potentials due to each charge.
The potential at a point due to a single positive charge decreases as you move away from the charge.
Figure (b) shows the electric potential phi as a function of position x along the ON axis, starting at sqrt(2)kQ/L at x = 0 and decreasing to kQ/L at x = sqrt(2)L.
Figure (c) shows the acceleration a of the small ball S1 as a function of x, increasing from g to 2g and then slightly decreasing towards x = sqrt(2)L.
The small ball S1 has a charge Q and is falling vertically from M to N, considering both gravitational and electric forces.
To find the electric force on S1 at point M, calculate the electric field due to each charge using Coulomb's law.
The electric field due to charge A at point M is E_A = kQ/r_AM^2 * r_AM.
The electric field due to charge B at point M is E_B = kQ/r_BM^2 * r_BM.
Since both A and B are at the same distance from M (sqrt(2)L), both E_A and E_B have the same magnitude: E = kQ/(2L^2).
The directions of E_A and E_B are along the lines from A to M and B to M, respectively, pointing away from A and B.
A is at some horizontal position to the left of O, B is at the same horizontal position to the right of O, O is the midpoint between A and B, and M is vertically above O at a distance of sqrt(2)L.
The lines from A to M and B to M make angles with the vertical.
Assuming the horizontal distance from O to A (or B) is L, the distance from A to B is 2L.
